reviews.review_text: Dead Space 2 is amazing. It takes everything the original put into the series, and enhances it. The controls are more precise, smooth and convenient (with the addition of a single button health and stasis refill system), the visuals are even more detailed and gritty, the sound is as creepy as ever, and the story remains intriguing and intense. You must work to unravel the truth behind the Sprawl (the game's setting), Unitology and Necromorphs, as well as battling (literally) horrific hallucinations and delusions from an alien form of dementia. If you are a fan of the first, then you will definitely enjoy this.  While the base game mechanics are not terribly different from many over-the-shoulder style third person shooters, several aspects are worth mentioning. One of the hallmarks of Dead Space 2 is that it forces players to use weapons to defeat enemies in a different way. In a time when headshots are the gold standard for 99% of games, Dead Space 2 requires players to sever limbs in order to defeat enemies--well-placed head shots will get you nowhere. This is a refreshing change of pace, as the dismemberment strategy will change based on enemy type (there are several), and thus every battle becomes much more tactical. There are also a wide variety of unique weapons to choose from, and each weapon will serve a different purpose in your arsenal, depending on how you want to fine tune your Necromorph killing strategy. Puzzles are frequent enough to serve as welcome breaks from the tense action, but not too frequent to become annoying.  Atmosphere was my main draw to DS1 and now DS2. Visceral Games has managed to create this incredibly immersive environment that manages to literally keep me trying to be prepared for what they may throw at me next. In my opinion, the number one contributor to creating such an unrivaled level of atmosphere is the sound design. Anyone who plays this game owes it to themselves to have it on a good home theater system or at least some good quality headphones. The surround sound not only adds to the spookiness of the game, but delivers vital information of approaching creatures. Even in areas with no baddies to kill, the sounds of metallic creaks, cracks and scrapes in the Sprawl's ventilation system let you know you're never safe. Indeed DS2 has some cheap scares, but they're so well timed and not always predictable that I have a hard time believing someone who says they never jumped during a play through.  The music is well composed, and only adds to the atmosphere. The music is also well timed and sometimes gives you the impression that something large is coming. Sometimes it never happens, while other times it does. It manages to build levels of tension and keep you on your toes, never taking for granted the next dark hallway, for a necro is commonly waiting in unseen corners.  Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Dead Space 2. One does not have to be familiar with the first to enjoy this, as there is a 'Previous on Dead Space' menu option available to bring newcomers up to par; however, to get the most from the story, I would highly recommend it.

The sequal to the original Dead Space game is good if not better in almost every aspect. Dead Space 2 continues the story of Dead Space 1 except Isac Clark not stranded on a ship anymore he's stranded on a space station instead. Even better he suffers from a form of dementia plaguing his mind and threatens to kill him in the form of his old wife Nicole (Lovely isn't it). New characters are introduced in Dead Space 2 Nolan Stose who suffers from the same syptoms and dementia Isacc does, Tidman who is a complete dumbass, and Ellie who could be a better waifu for Isacc than Nicole. The horror and gameplay in Dead Space 2 has improved and is much better compared to the original with more horror( especially scences where Isac's mind interfers and displays Nicole), more action, and more Oh ♥♥♥♥ moments. There are more suits and more weapons in Dead Space 2 giving players more stuff to experiment and play with. The suits now have special attributes tied to them like 10% more health recieved from health kits and 15% percent more damage with certain weapons. There are even more different kinds of necromorphs to kill and loot from them is obtained by stomping and smashing them (because who dosen't like that). The religous group in Dead Space 1 makes a return here with thier own church on the space station and so does the government with their government sector. Dead Space 2 is a better version of the orignal and is a must own for people who have played Dead Space 1. I do not recommend buying this on its own, instead buy the Dead Space 1 & 2 bundle and experience the best of both worlds.

Dead Space 2 is a gigantic, flying leap over Dead Space 1 in many ways.  Pros:      Dozens of gameplay refinements from Dead Space 1: Issac moves much easier and aims much faster, with animations getting almost complete overhaul ( for example, Issac's badass backhand is now replaced with a much faster punch, and his stomp comes out way faster and is much easier to spam). You can now pick up Necromorph blades or rods and shoot them into enemies, allowing you to deal with individual foes much easier and save ammo. New enemy types keep combat fresh, like introducing the long-range debuffing Puker or the agile Stalker to keep the player on their toes. New weapons make for a much more interesting combat experience, with interesting ideas like the Javelin Gun or the Detonator alongside classics like the Plasma Cutter, Line Gun and Pulse Rifle.     Beautiful graphics and sound: The game, while showing it's currently five year old age in a hell of a lot of places (like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRM, and long distance objects looking like crap) has some absolutely beautiful locations- standouts include the Government Sector, the Unitologist Church/Residence and more. Lighting effects are at their prime here, with detailed, colourful mood lighting that adds to the setpieces: having the only light be Issac's helmet glow is an effect that REALLY should have been used more often as it simply looks beautiful.     Good Story: Having Issac be voiced is a contentious decision, but I think it works. It helps that his voice acting is pretty good, and the story is much more engaging with him being voiced. Issac being mute in the last game was something I disliked, so it's nice to see him express himself here. The story is much more personal and cinematic this time around, and it has a good resolution at the end.    Replayability: Don't let my 7-ish hours ingame fool you- i've beaten DSII at least 4 times- 3 on PS3 and once on PC and   it's still a blast!  The myriad of weapons, unique combat encounters and wide tools almost demand multiple playthroughs, and the new game plus of this game is on the same tier of Resident Evil 4- just as fun as the first time through, though way easier. My total time with this game has been at least 23 hours total across all the playthroughs, and i've only spent about $20 on this game across buying it twice. It's got a lot of content.   Cons:  Too much action: The unfortunate side of things is that DSII is rarely scary. While DSI wasn't too scary either, it at least tried. DSII is full on action from start to finish, like Alien to Aliens. However, the truly spooky parts, like the first encounter with the stalkers in the church or the appearance of an old pal from DSI towards the end of the game are very memorable. It's a shame that the relentless action kinda ruins the atmosphere, because the creepy atmosphere in many locations can make your skin crawl.    Horrible Install: Despite running very well, the setup process for this game can be a real pain in the ♥♥♥. Seriously, it took me at least half an hour to get it working, and that's with no issues on my end.   Overall: An excellent action horror experience- by cutting off the fluff and refining the core of Dead Space combat, a truly great game was made. A classic everyone should try.

Dead Space 2 is a great horror game and a brilliant sequel to the another great horror game.  Set, I believe, three years after the events of the first game, Isaac Clarke wakes up in a psych ward in a hospital in a space station, just as the infection that wreaked havoc on the Ishimura (space ship) from the first game breaks out on this space station. Clarke makes his escape while having hallucinations but is also guided by a stranger. This is where the story really kicks off. Because I'm going to avoid giving away any spoilers, I'm just going to say that the person you hallucinate throughout the game is Nicole, Isaac's former love interest from the first game.  The brilliance of the horror elements in this game is that it isn't a jump scare type of game. It's genuinely terrifying because of the extent of damage done to this space station due to a breakout in the disease that transforms the people into these abominations of creatures. The most memorable part is, arguably, when you're in a nursery and you see a woman, still alive, trying to cradle her baby, who has visibly transformed. Well, the baby has a yellow, soft belly and if you've played the first game, you'll remember that the yellow areas are weak points prone to explode. You can probably guess what happens to the woman.  The soundtrack is nice but the game really shines when there isn't any music at all. Just the vast void of sound is so profound and the slightest creak will catch you off guard. The sound mixing in this game is done expertly. The graphics are stellar. I mean, I can tell it came out in 2011, but the lighting is so great and the textures on the walls and characters are generally fantastic. All around splendid job on graphics. The level design is done well enough where each chapter has a varied design. I especially loved the zero gravity flying around in space. The vastness of it, and being able to see Saturn in the distance (I'm pretty sure it's Saturn) is just so unique.  Anyway, I feel like I've said enough. Really, fantastic game. Highly recommend.  9.3/10

Dead Space 2 is a great survival horror experience that I feel like I should recommend to my gamer friends, but why do I say so?  First of all, it's a survival horror, which is quite a rare genre these days, but that doesn't influence my recommendation, I am merely stating this fact for you to keep in mind if you were searching something like this.  I finished the game in roughly 14 hours or so, with a good pace, exploring everything and playing at the survivalist difficulty, which is one grade higher than normal, as I saw in the forums, it is the best difficulty for someone wanting a challenge, instead of the highest which is zealot and is recommended for new game+.  The challenge was good, I was tense most of the time, never mind the jump scares, the ammo was pretty scarce and the enemies needed only two or three hits to take you down, and all this considering careful ammo and inventory management. I did end up with a surplus of health kits that I saved in my safe and sold all the stasis packs, but the ammo, I had to buy some of those. The gameplay is smoother from the first Dead Space, the character controls well and behaves like he should, which means you're not agile but you're not clunky either, it is a fine balance, although sometimes I wish I could roll out of the way I admit (which is not possible for the record). The horror part and the environment were pretty well done, I never did scream or anything, it wasn't that terrifying, but I was tense most of the time and the occasional 'F*ck' did come out of my mouth when confronted with jump scares or close encounters with numerous enemies. Which reminds me, most of the time I was collected and my aim was good, but the game did drive me in some corners where I panicked, which is definitely a plus in this genre. The only reasons I would not recommend this game are mainly two design flaws : 1.) No more than two bodies stay in the room, at the third body, the latest despawns, but what does this mean? It means that you need to stomp or otherwise damage enemies on the floor to get your drop (ammo, health, credits) and when the enemy despawns, so does the loot. Annoying to say the least. 2.) Death is mostly harmless with no repercussions to the player, hell it is even advantageous at some points. When you die, you get back at the checkpoint, so if you had full health at a check point and, for example, fell into a stupid trap that reduced your health to red, you can just die and retry again with full health again and no other penalty (Of course this doesn't apply to hard core mode, a mode you unlock when you finish the game that allows only 3 saves and forces you to reload when you die). Lastly I would like to talk about about the story in a short paragraph. The story continues from the first Dead Space of course, which I recommend to play too, but don't feel compelled to, everything is explained rather well I think. It's a good story, it has it's own charms, maybe a plot hole? Not sure. The good thing is I was genuinely surprised, not once but twice! The twist and turns were well done, it's not like I was looking forward to it, but it's definitely a plus when it's not reduced to a clichè and I didn't know what to expect.  I think I covered everything, the graphics were good, the music almost non-existant, the multiplayer was pretty fun and original, but anyways it's a pretty cool survival horror, those who like the genre should definitely play it, besides, you'll probably get it for spare change like me during sales, I think I paid 2 euros or something, definitely worth it.

This game kept me more interested than when I played DS1. I uninstalled DS1 after how boring the game was and enduring another failed port. I was always on the edge of my seat determined to get through as many chapters as possible in DS2. There were more interesting things in DS2 game than the typical cliche, predictable jump scares from DS1. Dead Space 2 added more life to the necromorphs and made them even more insanely disturbing than just alien zombies. Necromorphs are after all the basis of the Dead Space series. DS2 is when they turned from being random zombies to being very interesting, I begun to see all of their habits, predatory strategies and beyond. Another major difference I felt between the two games was how I felt unstoppable with my guns in DS1 and how I felt everything was turning out to a repetitive shooting gallery. I never felt the same way in DS2 since the the necromorphs were pretty powerful and aggressive even to the end of the game; I never felt overpowered, and always in danger.     In all, DS1 was a glorifed shoot zombies on spaceship game with spooky halls. You would face pretty much the same type of necromorphs, tactics and predictable, 'oh, ♥♥♥♥, someone got lazy and the ishimarua isn't working again-hold on for 30 minutes while you get swarmed by zombies and have to burn up all your ammo.' Now granted DS2 does have some of that very same action in comparison to DS1 there is more variety with the game. There are things like the tormentor, ubermorph, exploding door panels, the segment with the train, nolan stross, fleeing civilians, and tideman to ♥♥♥♥ up everything in your way forcing you to do things like repairing solar panels; all of these components make DS2 not seem as boring as DS1, and keep you interested in the 'background'. These things are all CONSTANT and remind you that your threat is not ONLY the necromorphs and brings you a sense the environment is alive.    This is a better game than DS2 and 1,3. Originally posted Feb 4 2011  gameaday-ish.blogspot.com   Many, many games make me wish for a “sigh” button, for a variety of reasons. Dead Space 2 makes me wish for a “sigh of despair” button.  Thrown into a startling and thrilling opening sequence, Isaac Clarke returns from Dead Space to once again dismember and destroy necromorphs. Arming himself in a plot-driven and organic way, Isaac also finds his voice, something that was missing in the first game. Spectacularly well written and well-acted, Isaac is no longer a silent avatar for the player, but a fully formed character whose destiny is to be plagued by waking nightmares.  Like a futuristic John Mclane, Isaac finds himself in a horribly familiar situation: running and fighting for his life through an industrial space maze, guided by remote voices. Unlike the errand missions and unending jump scares of the first game, DS 2 makes ironic meat of the first game’s formula with a half-way point reveal that is delicious. Replete with actual mood and atmosphere, DS 2 does have more than its fair share of jump scares, but makes up for it by honing tension to a bright gleaming point.  A few mid-to-late game set pieces tread dangerously close to vomiting all over the concept of over-the-top bad taste, but like any great horror experience makes the viewer squirm.   Caveats are few and far between, but like the overuse of jump-scares, DS 2 does milk its formula too much. Vacillating between random encounters against one or two enemies and endless swarms, DS 2 also swings heavily in difficulty level, especially in the late game. Combat and movement have been tweaked just enough to make the action quick and responsive, unlike the tank controls of the first game. While this makes the game move faster and become slightly more of an action-shooter, it makes the difficulty spikes more egregious as the need for accuracy ramps up beyond the speed of the controls.  Following the first game, DS 2 allows for a New Game+ mode, allowing the player to carry over any upgraded equipment from the 1st playthough, lowering the difficulty and increasing replayibility.   Satisfying in its resolution, DS 2 raises the bar beyond survival horror to become a truly cinematic horror experience and I can’t wait to play it again.

I'm no fan of the Dead Space games. In fact, I detest them. Dead Space 1 was, in a word, boring. Boring to the point that I barely remember anything about it. I remember the turret segments, which should have been awesome, were ruined by the atrocious controls, and I remember the two other people with Isaac being unlikeable jackasses. I haven't played Dead Space 3, and I really don't want to. Now, Dead Space 2 takes a cue from Empire Strikes Back and attempts to be better than the first game, which it manages to both succeed and fail at. The Sprawl is a great location to play through, being far more spacious and varied than the Ishimura, and we get a few glimpses of everyday life on the Sprawl. Isaac himself actually has characterization this time, albeit fairly clichéd, and most of the characters we interact with have different and compelling personalities, especially newcomer Ellie. Ellie and Isaac play off one another in ways that are both hilarious and heartbreaking, and it overall makes for better immersion.  Unfortunately, that's all I have to say that's positive. The biggest, most glaring problem is: this game is basically Dead Space 1 with a new paint job and a camper attached. Most of the enemies are copy-pasted from the first game, including the 'elite' recolors, gameplay is identical, the plot amounts to 'Dead Space 1, but on a space station,' the wide array of weapons is, again, completely pointless since the plasma cutter is all you really need, Isaac is lead along by a female character who betrays him in sight of the oh-so-special Marker, (two this time!), and the monsters keep jumping out of the exact same 'vent' (it doesn't actually go anywhere) as the first game. Oh, but wait! Now, there's extra varieties of incredibly obvious panels the monsters could be behind! Yahoo!  Now, onto the series' bread and butter; the gore and body horror. They're there and they're certainly creative, but they start losing what edge they might have had when they're in your face (literally) from the start of the game right up to the end. Much of the game's gore allowance was lavishly slapped onto Isaac's numerous death scenes...which you'll likely never see if you play at all competently.  In conclusion, Dead Space 1 is boring, Dead Space 2 is better but still boring, and Dead Space 3 doesn't look like it's worth the money spent.

You played the original Dead Space. You figure you can handle the sequel. You're got used to things getting jacked up to 11 while running through the corridors of the Ishimura. You're wrong. Because for the entirety of your life, you misunderstood how numbers work. What you thought was an eleven was actually a three. Dead Space 2? It teaches you about 11. You'll understand it all too well, before the end.  Continuing after the first installment, Dead Space 2 is a loveable mixture of Silent Hill and Mass Effect. To call it a third person 'corridor shooter' would do it an injustice, as the dev team did an excellent job of making the environments feel lived in and plausible. When you stop to reflect on the sheer amount of locales present in the sequel--mental wards, shopping malls, apartment complexes and mining facilities (to name a few)--you could be forgiven for thinking that Dead Space 2 is a long, hard grind. Except that it doesn't feel that way. You're fighting for your life--frequently running away, screaming--and you never have enough ammunition, health, or power nodes.  As an added bonus for purchasing the game on Steam, you'll have access to every weapon and most sets of armor as soon as you have access to your first in-game store kiosk. Even better, these items are free of charge, allowing you to save your money on upgrades, extra fuel for your flamethrower, and precious, precious medical attention. The action is considerably more fluid this time around, the pacing is excellent, there are memorable characters trying to survive alongside you and --  . . .  The light bulb across the room burnt out. Logically, I know it has nothing whatsoever to do with a marker (or necromorphs). And yet, I had to stop myself to formulate that sentence--such is the grip of Dead Space 2. You feel present in this nightmare vision of humanity's future that you are honestly jumpy when an incandescent bulb near you radiates its last lumens.  The replacement bulb is downstairs.  That's a long way in the dark.

I originally played this on Xbox 360 before I made the move to PC gaming. I think its actually impossible to be scared by DS2, so long as you played the first game first. In DS1 Isaac never spoke, it made it feel like the NPC's were talking directly to you, the player, it put you fully in his shoes, YOU were the character. For me that was what made the original Dead Space so immersive and so f***ing terrifying - that and the horrifying man in the wall monsters.  They threw that out of the window in this one by having Isaac talk, sure it makes sense from a story point of view but it takes you out of his shoes and completely detaches you, makes you an outsider looking in, like any other game.  That gripe aside this is still an awesome game, graphically a lot better than the first, hacking up necromorphs and impaling them with their own limbs is still as satisfyingly gruesome, and the stomping has been improved, now instead of one thud at a time you can keep on mashing that stomp until Isaac gets all angry and swears at the gloopy corpse under his feet. Another big improvement over the first is the zero G sections, where in the first game you'd have to slowly jump from point to point, in DS2 you now have full 360 degree flight with reaction thrusters on your suit, and this has been incorporated into some great puzzles involving the stasis module, pipes and fans.  It still has its spooky moments and unexpected googlieman surprises but they lack the impact of the first game, and after an hour of playing you'll be completely desensitized to it. My final comment is that I have not encountered any possibly game-breaking bugs like I had with the predecessor. I did not need to tinker around my in-game settings or graphics control panel to alleviate something that should not have posed as a problem in the first place. Awesome game. It's one of the best action/ horror games I've ever played... On console.  The horror aspects are great, with atmospheric sounds being creepier than the actual jump scares. That takes skill to acomplish and always put me on edge. Enemy designs are also worth a mention, since the Necromorph (alien/ human hybrids) are all creepy and haunting, to say the least. Not to mention, there are a lot of varying enemy types to fight against, each requiring different ways to cleanly kill them to preserve ammo and slow them down. Just like Dead Space 1, dismemberment is crucial to progression in harder difficulties, since you need to learn how to quickly kill certain enemies before they rip you apart.  The story is interesting, but without going into spoiler region, I can safely say it's quite forgetable ina lot of parts, but is strong with it's backstory. I always wanted to listen to audiologs or read articles about the lore, since it differs greatly from other horror games, adding a sci fi mix to the genre. It's best you make your own decision, but I mainly played for the experience.  There is a large amount of upgrades to acquire, as well as weapons that can be upgraded. Multiple playthroughs are to be expected to futher strengthen your arsenal and character (Isaac Clarke). Overall, this game is a lot of fun (when it works) and is definitely worth a play. But, I acn not reccomend this version, since there are no patches to fix my issue.
